text.p: Following are some of the major events to have occurred on February 11 in history.
1573 - English explorer Francis Drake first saw the Pacific Ocean.
1847 - Thomas Alva Edison, U.S. inventor who registered over 1,000 patents, born; his patents included those on the gramophone and the incandescent light bulb.
1858 - Saint Bernadette of Lourdes, originally Marie-Bernarde Soubirous, first saw a vision of the Virgin Mary at Lourdes, France, leading to the foundation of the shrine of Lourdes.
1868 - Jean Foucault, French physicist and inventor of the gyroscope, died in Paris.
1873 - Amadeo, king of Spain, abdicated, leading to the proclamation of the first Spanish republic.
1879 - Honore Daumier, French caricaturist, painter and sculptor, died. In 1832 he was imprisoned for six months for a caricature of Louis-Philippe.
1889 - The Japanese constitution was granted, with a two-chamber parliament, but the Emperor retained extensive powers.
1919 - Friedrich Ebert was elected first president of the German republic. He helped bring about the Weimar constitution that tried to unite Germany after World War One.
1920 - King Farouk, king of Egypt 1936-52, born; he was ousted in a coup led by Gamal Abdul Nasser in July 1952.
1922 - Honduras was declared an independent republic.
1929 - The Lateran Treaty was signed establishing an independent Vatican State in Rome.
1931 - Sir Charles Algernon Parsons, English steam turbine engineer and inventor, died.
1940 - John Buchan, Scottish author of "Thirty Nine Steps", died.
1945 - The Yalta Conference between Churchill, Stalin and Roosevelt ended with agreeement on the founding of the U.N., as well as plans for the defeat of Germany.
1949 - Axel Martin Fredrik Munthe, Swedish physician and writer, author of "The Story of San Michele", died.
1960 - Erno Dohnanyi, Hungarian composer, pianist and conductor, died. Best known for his piano compositions, most notably "Variation on a Nursery Theme".
1970 - Japan became the fourth country to put a satellite into orbit.
1975 - Margaret Thatcher became the first woman leader of a British political party when she was elected leader of the Conservatives.
1975 - In the Malagasy Republic, President Richard Ratsimandrava was assassinated after only six days in office.
1976 - Britain and the Organisation of African Unity recognised the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola.
1976 - Lee J. Cobb, U.S. film actor, died; his films included "On the Waterfront" and "The Brothers Karamazov".
1979 - Iranian Prime Minister Dr. Shahpur Bakhtiar resigned after two days of fighting in the streets of Tehran.
1990 - Nelson Mandela, black nationalist leader in South Africa was released from prison after serving 27 years.
1993 - Former prime minister Bettino Craxi resigned as leader of Italy's Socialists over a corruption scandal that had rocked the government.
1994 - The U.N. commander in Sarajevo accused renegade troops of trying to sabotage a ceasefire in the city but warring Moslems and Serbs began to turn in some of their heavy weapons.
1994 - U.S. President Bill Clinton and Japanese Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa failed to reach a critical trade deal.
1994 - Five astronauts and a cosmonaut returned to Earth aboard Discovery after the first joint U.S.-Russian space shuttle mission.
1996 - A crowd of up to a million turned out for Pope John Paul II's last mass of his Latin American tour and heard him denounce the corruption of Venezuelan society.
